Background

OpenStax is a nonprofit textbook publisher based at Rice University, and it’s our mission to improve student access to education. Our first openly licensed college textbook was published in 2012, and our library has since grown to more than 20 books for college and AP courses used by hundreds of thousands of students.

Design is directed by an OpenStax team in collaboration with external groups and subject matter experts in their respective fields. Team participants may vary between titles under development.

Our Process

Github

The primary venue of collaboration between OpenStax and vendors is GitHub, where our code repositories and project management tools reside.

Our code repository is available (privately) at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

New collaborators

In order to gain access to the OpenStax repository, oer.exports, which holds our code and issue management tools, perform the following tasks:

  1. If you do not have a GitHub account, create one.

    • Go to http://www.github.com/.
    • Enter the requested information and click Sign up for GitHub.

  2. Send your GitHub username to Alana Lemay-Gibson nyxer@rice.edu, and Alina Slavik alinams@rice.edu.

    Our A-team will then setup your access to the Connexions / oer.exports repository. You will receive an invitation email from GitHub with a link to follow to accept access, or you may visit https://github.com/Connexions where you can find a link to accept access at the top.

  3. Visit the OpenStax repository at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

Report and track an issue with a textbook template

To submit an issue for an OpenStax textbook, perform the following tasks:

  1. Ensure that you are logged into GitHub:

    • If you are not logged into GitHub, the Sign in button displays in the upper, right corner of the page.
    • If you are logged into GitHub, your username display in the upper, right corner of the page.

  2. From the links menu on the top of the page, click Issues.

  3. Click New Issue.

  4. To create the issue, enter the following information:

    • At Title, enter a title for the issue. Please include the name of the textbook in the title, then use a colon and type a summary of the issue, e.g. "Economics: Feature titles 10 pixels too far left".
    • At no one is assigned, click the gear button and select nyxer95 to assign the issue to the Project Manager.

    • At Leave a comment, enter the following information:

      1. Rendition in which you encountered the issue, e.g. HTML, PDF, etc.
      2. Chapter and Module number.
      3. A detailed (quantitative and qualitative) description of the issue.

    • At Add Labels, click to select a value from all of the following label groups:

      1. book
      2. env
      3. prio
      4. type

    • Locate the screen captures of the issue and drag them into the comment section of the page.

      To ensure that your screen captures are inserted properly, click Preview.

    • Click Submit new issue

To track issues that you submitted, perform the following tasks:

  1. Go to https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports/issues?state=open.

  2. From Browse Issues, click Created by you.

  3. If you want to see only the issues related to a specific book, click one of the book labels.

Questions

If you have any questions about how to use GitHub to track issues related to OpenStax textbook development, please contact the Project Manager for OpenStax, Alana Lemay-Gibson, at nxyer@rice.edu

Content servers

A list of our servers and their purposes is available in our Textbook Team Servers document.

Report an issue with a content development staging server.

  1. Complete the following email template:
  2. Subject Line: URGENT: Work Stoppage on Textbook Staging Server

  3. Message Body: We don't have access to the server at address: _____________. It has been down for __ [minutes/hour(s)]. This is causing work stoppage.

  4. Include a brief statement of the nature of the outage (text or screenshot of the error message, etc.).

  5. Email the completed template to [partner name]@openstax.org.

Cc other members of your team as appropriate.

Limitations

One of our methods of improving access to education is lowering cost, and in our effort to do so we have adopted methods of textbook production which many may find unfamiliar. We rely heavily on technology that provides automated content layout and composition for print. This allows us to quickly change content and style, but it also leads to many unique problems. We will investigate some of those problems in detail.

A list of GitHub Issues which relate to these platform limitations is maintained using a status:wontfix label.

Page count

A large factor in textbook cost is the length of the text, and we have made the decision to sacrifice the quality of our layout and composition in order to lower student cost by reducing page count. This means that if a text is too long to print, we will adjust the style to lower the page count -- usually resulting in a lower quality textbook. Vertical space is extremely valuable, and should never be wasted. With regards to breaking this rule, only the most vital pedagogical features will be considered.

Our hardcover textbooks are limited to 1700 pages. We prefer a page count considerably lower, to increase accessibility and affordability.

While we acknowledge that white space, or negative space, is an active element in a good design, we have traded manual control of this type of pixel-perfect layout for software algorithms that place content into a paged layout quickly. This means that adding or removing whitespace can be difficult, or impossible, especially where content breaks across pages or where it has been set into multiple columns.

Column Layouts

Only specific content, such as collated material, can be organized into columns. The primary body text of each chapter is limited to one column. Markup and instruction will be provided in a tagging legend if a title supports organizing content into a column layout.

Text wrapping

Our platform does not support wrapping text around images.

Math and scientific notation

Our publishing platform does not completely support the features of the MathML language. We cannot use colors, certain roots outside the radical, or many features of vertical math. We have documented MathML Guidelines to help avoid some of these problems or introducing others.

Page breaking

  • Any kind of forced page breaks should be kept to a minimum. Without the ability to control placement of each piece of content individually, forcing elements such as tables or other varying length content to break will lead to unintended white space on a page and potentially increase page count significantly. Limiting forced page breaks also helps avoid problems if content is reused.
  • Chapters, appendices, and some collated material will appear after an automatic page break that will force such content to appear on an odd, right hand side, page.
  • Content is allowed to break within tables unless otherwise specified.
  • Content is allowed to break inside a feature unless otherwise specified.
  • Restrictions to natural content breaks may occur in exercises, examples, or other content. End of chapter material might have specific page breaking rules to ensure that exercise titles remain with the exercise problems. Sometimes breaks will be forced so that exercises flow evenly when in columns. These typically depend on the complexity of the layout and/or content.
GENERAL COMPOSITION

Color

OpenStax textbooks are primarily in four subjects: Mathematics, Science, Business, and Humanities. There are four general "themes" that specify the style for our titles in these markets.

Themes

Mathematics

Science

Business

Humanities

Source Art

Source art should use colors from the primary palette from a specific markets theme.

Typography

A double-stranded scale (Perfect Fifth and Perfect Fourth) is used to determine text sizes. Vertical space, padding or margin, will be determined using a method that will ensure that all text is composed in such a way that vertical space is divided into portions equal in height to the product of font size and line height.

All text will land on a vertical position that is an integer multiple of (base font size * base line height). Base font size, as well as line height, can be changed during production for a number of reasons, the most common being textbook length. Longer titles may require text to have less line height, or a smaller font size. Limiting text sizes to specific ratios, and determining vertical spaces relative to that text size, ensures that we can change text properties in a predictable way. All vertical spaces will adjust at the same ratios as text sizes change.

Fonts

Our books generally use a combination of Noto Sans, Noto Serif, and Dosis.

  • Noto Sans, Noto Serif
  • Dosis, Noto Sans
  • Dosis, Noto Serif

Mathematics

Mathematics is rendered using STIX Fonts Project fonts. These fonts are licensed SIL Open Font License (OFL-1.1).

Page Layout

Page dimensions are 8.5 x 11 inches. Top and bottom margins are 0.8 inch, left and right margins are 1 inch.

The page is split into margins, folio (page header and footer), and a content area. Numbers and generated content (such as surrent page number, current chapter title, etc) can appear in the folio areas. An attribution link is automatically added to the footer of all even-numbered pages.

Image Layout

We support full width, two column, and three column sets of images, figures, and problems/solutions.
Content Elements

Folio

All OpenStax books have folio text at the top of the page on all pages after the table of contents. This text includes the number and title of the chapter (or Preface, Appendix, or Index) aligned to the inside of the page, opposite the page number. These folios are automatically generated in the pdf and cannot be edited manually.

Content Headers

OpenStax books use nested headers; they include chapter titles (H1), module titles (H2), inside-module section titles (H3), and further nested section headers (e.g. H4, H5). These header levels can be distinguished from each other by CSS-assigned font size and style.

Paragraphs

Paragraphs cannot be referred or linked to in OpenStax books, nor can they be indented without being enclosed by some other container.

Links

Our books use several types of links, each with different markup requirements: + external links, which go to a non-OpenStax website (usually with a forwarding shortlink from openstax.org), marked up with anchor text + Intramodule links, which go to an element inside the same module as the link, and are marked up with with no anchor text, since the linked feature’s title or number will be automatically generated when the link displays + extramodule links, which go to another module inside the book collection, marked up with Module Title anchor text (these links may also go to a specific feature inside the other module, in which case the link markup will include target-id="id of the target element" inside the link tag, and the link will not require anchor text)

Lists

Lists may be bulleted, unmarked, stepwise, numbered, alphabetical, or tokened. Certain lists may also be comma-separated and not vertically separated by item.

Blockquotes

Blockquotes are indented and may have a specified font style, and use the tag.
Dividers

Footnotes

Numbered footnotes are available in OpenStax books with the <footnote> tag, which encloses the text of the footnote and moves it to the bottom of the page on which the tag appears.

Footer

Every even-numbered page of an OpenStax book has an automatically-generated footer stating the book’s free availability and location online.

Footer Image

Figures

A <figure> tag is a container for a media tag, and figures are numbered by default. To remove numbering from a figure, the unnumbered class must be applied in the figure tag (the markup is <figure class="unnumbered">), and an empty label tag (<label/>) must also be enclosed inside the figure tag. Figures may have captions (the markup <caption> goes inside the figure tag), but they are not required.

Images

  • Images must be uploaded to the module they will appear in on the platform, and they show up in the content when referred to by filename in a <media> tag: <media alt="alt text"> <image src="filename.jpg"/> </media>
  • An alt text description of the image is required on each piece of media, for accessibility.
  • Images are unnumbered by default and do not have a caption, but can be numbered if enclosed by a figure tag.
  • Image files supported: png (including transparency), svg, jpg, gif
  • [[target for image sizes from figure] Image can be 3 sizes: ⅓, ½, full width. Exact measurements to be provided at a later date

UI Elements

  • Icons
  • Borders

Features

  • Simple features: some features have an automatically-generated feature title (Try It, for example) which is provided by the CSS once a class is applied to the <note> tag enclosing the feature.
  • Subtitled features: some features have an automatically generated feature title as well as manually applied subtitles for each individual feature. These subtitles are sometimes applied in the <title> tag of the note, but other times they are text inside a paragraph in the note.
  • Features may or may not be numbered according to their class.

Examples

  • Examples may contain exercises with solutions (an <exercise> tag contains a <problem> tag and may also contain one or more <solution> tags; <commentary> is another available child of the <exercise> tag). Solutions to exercises inside Examples have automatic numbering corresponding to the Example numbers.
  • Examples may have subtitles, with either only a visual distinction (bolded manually in a paragraph enclosed inside the example), but the subtitles may also be created by applying specific classes to the <example> tag.

Tables

  • Basic tables are are numbered by default. Tables may have a title and/or a caption. The title appears after the table number and before the caption below the table.
  • To remove the numbering from a table, both apply the class="unnumbered" in the <table> tag and include an empty label tag (marked up as <label/> enclosed by the table tag).
  • To create a table with a header row, include a <thead> row before the other rows. Header rows are incompatible with a forced "Title" above a table within the same book.
  • To create a forced "Title" above a table instead the normal table title below it, merge the cells in the header row and put the "Title" in the merged cell. Tables with forced titles above the data can contain a caption, but no <title> tag is needed. These tables can be unnumbered. Forced titles above the data are incompatible with single header rows within the same book.
  • To create a forced "Title" above a table with a header row, use two <thead> rows, with the first one's cells merged. These tables can contain a caption, but no <title> tag is needed. Two-thead tables are incompatible with double-header-row tables within the same book.
  • To create a table with two header rows, use two <thead> rows, unmerged. These tables may have a caption and a title. They are incompatible with tables that have both forced "Title" rows above them and a header row, within the same book.
  • Unstyled tables use the class "unstyled" in conjunction with the class "unnumbered" (the markup is <table class="unnumbered unstyled">). These have no borders or styling and are aligned left by default.
  • To create a column header in a table, use the class "column-header" on the <table> tag.
  • To create "header" rows inside a table, merge the cells in the row and bold the text in the markup for the merged cell. More styling, such as colored text or colored background of the cells, is not supported by the platform.
Skelebook (default book map)
Front Matter (manually added)

Preface

The <document> tag of a preface must contain the preface class: <document class="preface">.

Table of Contents

The platform automatically generates a table of contents; it cannot be edited manually.

Chapter

Modules

Each chapter contains an introduction module. This module must use the class "introduction" (not "intro", which is a common markup mistake) in the document tag: <document class="introduction">. A chapter also contains one or more other modules. These are contained in a subcollection inside the collection structure. Modules may contain any available CNXML content.

Splash image

At the beginning of each chapter in the introduction module, a figure with the splash class (markup: <figure class="splash"> may cover the horizontal width of the page.

Chapter outline

The platform generates a chapter outline for each chapter in the collection.

Learning Objectives (not in every book)

At the beginning of each chapter, and also at the beginning of each module, learning objectives are defined in the content, using a section with the class learning-objectives (the beginning of the module is marked up this way: <section class="learning-objectives">, with a bulleted list of objectives inside the section tag).

End-of-Chapter Collated Elements

  • Collating elements are created by adding a specific class to a <section> tag at the end of a module (these elements must always appear in the same order in the module markup). Collating elements common to most OpenStax books include Section Summary (class="section-summary"), Key Terms (class="key-terms"), Key Concepts (class="concepts"), Key Equations, various types of problems and exercises (often separated in collation by type). More flexible book-specific collated elements sometimes include Practice Tests and References link to References.
  • Collating elements are usually located inside the relevant modules and collated together at the end of the chapter, using a collation instruction in the introduction module of each chapter. The collated elements may be separated by headers indicating the module they came from, or they may not, according to their class.

Answer Key

  • The Answer Key has exercise solutions that are separated by chapter in the back of the book.
  • Collation instructions for the Answer Key are included in the Introduction module of every chapter. There are two options; one will move any solutions inside the matched section to the end of chapter and add a copy of that to the answer key. Another will COPY any solutions inside the matched section to the answer key, also leaving it in place in the chapter.

References (not in every book)

  • May appear at the end of section, chapter, or book.
  • If displaying at the end of a book, they cannot be sorted at the book-level.

Appendix(es)

  • Appendixes are titled with alpha numbering (instead of the arabic numeral default of the rest of the book), and all numbered elements inside (tables, figures)
  • The document tag must contain the class "appendix".
  • The folio displays usual page numbers and appendix titles (Appendix A for example) instead of chapter title.
  • The appendix styling is similar to the rest of the book.

Index

  • Index terms are based on how they are referenced in the text and can only contain one word, e.g. “bank” and “banks” would be separate entries. An entry for “Clinton”, 2, 5, 25, 178 could refer to either Bill or Hillary.
